newsitem.title: CHILE: Peru, Ecuador to begin full-scale border talks.
newsitem.headline: Peru, Ecuador to begin full-scale border talks.

text.p: Peru and Ecuador will start serious talks for a final settlement to their Amazon border dispute by the end of the year, the two countries said on Tuesday after a round of negotiations in Chile.

The two neighbours, who went to war briefly in January, will meet in the Brazilian capital to iron out the remaining "impasses" that have blocked an agreement, their foreign ministers said in a statement.
"Ecuador and Peru will open conversations of a substantive nature in Brasilia before the end of 1996, with the purpose of reaching an overall and definitive solution," said the statement.
Dubbed the Santiago Agreement, the accord appeared to mark a major step toward solving the simmering border conflict between Peru and Ecuador over a remote stretch of Amazon jungle.
The two sides set the frontier under a 1942 peace treaty but Ecuador later renounced the pact, saying it signed under pressure.

Ecuadorean Foreign Minister Galo Leoro and his Peruvian counterpart Francisco Tudela signed the accord at a ceremony with Chilean President Eduardo Frei, along with representatives of the 1942 treaty's guarantors Chile, Argentina, Brazil and the United States.

The Brasilia talks will take place "in a spirit of reciprocal understanding and friendly respect," said the agreement, in sharp contrast to the blistering nationalistic rhetoric that has characterised the conflict on both sides.
The four guarantor countries will name a follow-up committee to assist the talks, though the committee's exact role was not made clear.

But in a clear sign the 1942 treaty will stay in force -- a long-standing Peruvian demand -- the agreement said the talks will take place in "conformity" with that treaty and three accords negotiated since early 1995.
"The conversations will be carried out in a nonstop and continuous way until their final conclusion," said the agreement, adding they will mean concessions on both sides.
The Peru-Ecuador conflict, which has occasionally flared up into shooting throughout this century, is currently the most delicate of about half a dozen border rows lingering around Latin America.
